title: 105_s1675
content: The Act may be cited as the "Congressional Office of Regulatory Analysis Act". Congress finds that Federal regulations can have a positive impact on protecting the environment and the health and safety of Americans, but uncontrolled increases in regulatory costs on the economy are unsustainable. The legislative branch must ensure proper implementation of laws by the executive branch, and effective implementation of congressional review of agency rulemaking is crucial in controlling the regulatory burden on the economy. Accurate and reliable information is necessary for the legislative branch to fulfill its responsibilities under title 5 of the United States Code. The purpose of this Act is to establish a congressional office to provide Congress with independent analyses of Federal rules and regulations, including assessments of their need, effectiveness, economic impacts, and effects on different segments of the public. Establishment of Office. The Congressional Office of Regulatory Analysis is established and headed by a Director appointed without political affiliation. The Director serves a 4-year term with a limit of 3 terms. Vacancies are filled for the unexpired portion of the term. The Director of the Congressional Office of Regulatory Analysis can continue serving until a successor is appointed. They can be removed by a resolution of Congress and receive compensation equal to a position at level III of the Executive Schedule. The Director appoints personnel based on fitness, prescribes their duties, and can delegate authority. The Director of the Congressional Office of Regulatory Analysis can delegate authority to perform duties and functions, treat personnel as Senate employees for pay and benefits, procure services of experts or consultants, and secure information directly from the Executive Branch. The Director of the Congressional Office of Regulatory Analysis can obtain information, data, estimates, and statistics from various government departments and agencies, including the Office of Management and Budget, for the performance of duties. Services, facilities, and personnel can be used with the agreement of department heads. The Director of the Congressional Office of Regulatory Analysis is authorized to obtain information, data, estimates, and statistics from other congressional agencies like the General Accounting Office, Congressional Budget Office, and the Library of Congress for effective coordination and utilization of resources. The Office of Regulatory Analysis can utilize services and personnel from the General Accounting Office, Congressional Budget Office, and Library of Congress. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 1998 through 2006 to support the Office's duties. SEC. 4. RESPONSIBILITIES. Transfer of functions under Chapter 8 from GAO to Office, Director's authority amended to Director of the Office, definition of Director of the Office added, Office to conduct regulatory impact analysis for major rules. The Office will conduct its own regulatory impact analysis for major rules, evaluating potential benefits, costs, and net benefits of the rule. The Office conducts regulatory impact analysis for major rules, evaluating benefits, costs, and alternative approaches to achieve regulatory goals at a lower cost. The analysis includes effects that cannot be quantified in monetary terms and a comparison of results with similar analyses conducted by the promulgating agency. The Office prioritizes conducting analyses of major rules to ensure significant regulations are thoroughly evaluated. Nonmajor rules may also undergo analysis upon request by a committee or individual in Congress. The Office assigns priority to requests from committees and individual Senators and Representatives, with the Director having discretion to prioritize among them. Certain functions under the Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995 are transferred from CBO to the Office, with amendments made to Section 103 regarding the cost of regulations. The Unfunded Mandates Reform Act of 1995 is amended to include the Director of the Congressional Office of Regulatory Analysis in certain sections, transferring functions from the Congressional Budget Office to the new office. The Office will issue an annual report estimating the total cost of Federal regulations on the US economy. The Act and its amendments will become effective 180 days after enactment.
